tn.text: Yahweh speaks about his people as if they were his children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: this is the declaration of Yahweh
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "declaration" is expressed as the verb "solemnly said." AT: "this is what Yahweh has declared" or "this is what Yahweh has solemnly said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: They make plans, but not from me
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "plans" can be stated as the verb "plan." AT: "They plan to do things, but they do not ask me what I want them to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: but they were not directed by my Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but my Spirit did not direct them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Continuing to sin is spoken of as if sins were objects that could be stacked on one another. AT: "they continue to sin more and more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "protection" is expressed as the verb "protect." AT: "They ask Pharaoh to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: take refuge in the shadow of Egypt
tn.text: Egypt's protection from enemy armies is spoken of as if it were a shadow that protects someone from the burning heat of the sun. AT: "they rely on the Egyptians to keep them safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Judah.

tn.ref: Therefore Pharaoh's protection will be your shame, and the refuge in Egypt's shade, your humiliation
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract nouns "protection," "shame," and "humiliation" are expressed as adjectives or verbs. AT: "Therefore you will be ashamed because you relied on Pharaoh to protect you; you will be humiliated because you relied on the Egyptians to keep you safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Egypt's protection from enemy armies is spoken of as if it were a shadow that protects someone from the burning heat of the sun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "princes" mean an official or ambassador, not necessarily sons of the king.
These words refer to the people of Judah.
These were cities in the northern part of Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "come" can be stated as "gone." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"because of the people of Egypt"
This continues God's declaration concerning the people of Judah.
"This is what Yahweh declares"

tn.ref: of the lioness and the lion, the viper and fiery flying serpent
tn.text: This refers to these types of animals in general. AT: "where lionesses and lions dwell, and where there are vipers and serpents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])
Here the word "fiery" probably refers to the serpent's poisonous bite and the word "flying" refers to its quick movements. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:14:28|14:29]].
"the people of Judah carry their riches"

tn.ref: I have called her Rahab, who sits still
tn.text: There were popular stories about a sea monster named Rahab. The name Rahab means "strength" or "arrogance." AT: "I call Egypt a loud boaster who does nothing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Yahweh continues speaking to Isaiah.
This word is used here to mark a break in Yahweh's declaration about Judah. Here he tells Isaiah to do something.
"in the presence of the people of Judah"
This speaks of time as if it travels and arrives somewhere. AT: "for a future time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: lying children, children who will not hear the instruction of Yahweh
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh's people as if they were his children. This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "They behave like children who lie and do not listen to what Yahweh commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh continues speaking about the people of Judah.

tn.ref: Turn aside from the way, stray off the path
tn.text: How Yahweh wants his people to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path on which to walk. To disobey Yahweh is spoken of as if the person strays away from Yahweh's path. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Translate this the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:04|1:4]].
Translate this the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:04|1:4]].
Here "word" represents a message. AT: "you reject this message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: trust in oppression and deceit and lean on it
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the leaders of Judah are trusting in the Egyptian leaders who rule by oppressing and deceiving others or 2) the leaders of Judah have oppressed and deceived their own people in order to take their money and send it to the Egyptians leaders as payment for protection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "it" refers to "oppression and deceit." AT: "lean on them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is an idiom that means to trust or rely on something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: so this sin will be to you like a broken part ... in an instant
tn.text: This simile means that God will destroy the people of Judah suddenly because of their sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: like a broken part ready to fall
tn.text: It is understood that this is a broken part of a wall. AT: "like a broken part of a wall that is ready to fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "fall" is expressed as the verb "fall." AT: "that will suddenly fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
These mean the same thing and emphasize how quickly the wall will fall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Isaiah describes how Yahweh will destroy the people of Judah. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:30:12|30:12-13]])

Here "it" refers to the part in the wall that is about to fall. The part in the wall is a metaphor that represents the people of Judah and their sin mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:30:12|30:12-13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: as a potter's vessel is broken
tn.text: This simile means that the piece of wall will break as quickly and completely as a clay jar that falls to the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
A potter is a person who makes pots and jars out of clay.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one will be able to find" or "there will not be" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a shard with which to scrape
tn.text: "a shard big enough to scrape"
The word "fire" here refers here to ashes. AT: "ashes from the fireplace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Translate this the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:01:04|1:4]].

tn.ref: In returning and resting you will be saved
tn.text: Repenting is spoken of as if it were physically returning to Yahweh. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will save you from your enemies if you will repent and rest knowing that I will take care of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
It is implied that the people rest because they trust that Yahweh will take care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in quietness and in trust will be your strength
tn.text: Quietness here refers to not being anxious and worried. It is implied that they are not worried because they trust in Yahweh. AT: "You will be strong if you are quiet and trust in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Apparently these are horses that the people of Judah received from the Egyptians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: One thousand will flee at the threat of one; at the threat of five you will flee
tn.text: The word "solider" is understood. AT: "One thousand soldiers will flee at the threat of one enemy soldier; at the threat of five enemy soldiers all of your soldiers will flee" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"1,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: until your remnant will be like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain, or like a flag on a hill
tn.text: This simile means there will be so few people left that they will be like a single flag on top of a hill. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.

tn.ref: you will ... to you ... answer you
tn.text: Here "you" refers to the people who will live in Zion.
"he will help you"
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.

tn.ref: the bread of adversity and the water of affliction
tn.text: Here "bread" and "water" make up the diet of a very poor person. The whole phrase represents the hard times and poverty of the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: you will see your teacher with your own eyes
tn.text: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. AT: "you yourselves will see your teacher" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "ears" represents the whole person. AT: "You will hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "word" represents the person speaking. AT: "him speaking behind you saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: This is the way, walk in it
tn.text: How Yahweh wants his people to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path. To obey Yahweh is spoken of as if it were a person walking on his path. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: when you turn to the right or when you turn to the left
tn.text: Disobeying Yahweh is spoken of as if the person turned left or right off of Yahweh's path. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.

tn.ref: You will throw them away like a menstrual rag
tn.text: This simile means they will throw away their idols like they were garbage. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: You will say to them, "Get out of here"
tn.text: This speaks of the idols as if they could hear and get up and leave a place. Yahweh means that the people will no longer need or want the idols. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.
"Yahweh will give"

tn.ref: bread with abundance from the ground
tn.text: Here "bread" represents food in general. AT: "he will cause the ground to produce plenty of food for you to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: that has been winnowed with a shovel and a fork
tn.text: Shovels and forks were used to throw the grain in the air so the wind would blow away the chaff, leaving only the part that could be eaten. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that you have winnowed with a shovel and a pitchfork" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.

tn.ref: On every high mountain ... sunlight of seven days
tn.text: Isaiah describes what will be an ideal situation after Yahweh rescues his people. Although the language may be exaggerated, you should translate this just as Isaiah described it.

tn.ref: in the day of the great slaughter when the towers fall
tn.text: "when Yahweh slaughters your enemies and causes their strong towers to fall"
Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "at the time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the light of the sun will be seven times brighter, like the sunlight of seven days
tn.text: "the sun will shine as bright as seven suns" or "the sun will give as much light in one day as it normally does in seven days"

tn.ref: Yahweh will bind up the breaking of his people and heal the bruises of his wounding them
tn.text: Yahweh comforting his people and causing their suffering to end is spoken of as if he would put bandages on their wounds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the name of Yahweh ... like a devouring fire
tn.text: Yahweh being extremely angry is spoken of as if he were a large fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "name" represents Yahweh. AT: "Yahweh comes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: His lips are full of fury, and his tongue is like a devouring fire
tn.text: Here "lips" and "tongue" are metonyms that represent Yahweh speaking. And, Yahweh speaks with so much anger and power that it is spoken of as if his tongue were a fire. AT: "When he speaks his fury is like a fire that destroys everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: His breath is like an overflowing torrent
tn.text: This compares the air coming out of Yahweh's mouth to a flood to emphasize its power to destroy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: to sift the nations with the sieve of destruction
tn.text: Yahweh separating the people of the nations and destroying the wicked people is spoken of as if Yahweh puts the nations in a sieve. This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "Yahweh will separate and destroy the wicked people of the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: His breath is a bridle in the jaws of the peoples to cause them to wander away
tn.text: Yahweh having the power to cause people's plans to fail or causing them to be destroyed is spoken of as if his breath were a bridle that steers people off the correct path. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a bridle in the jaws of the peoples
tn.text: A "bridle" is a device that people put over a horse's head to guide it. The bridle contains a small piece called a "bit" that goes in the horse's mouth. AT: "a bridle on the heads of the peoples" or "a bit in the jaws of the peoples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Isaiah continues speaking to the people of Judah.
This can be reworded so the abstract noun "song" is stated as a verb. AT: "You will sing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: as in the night when a holy feast is observed
tn.text: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: when a holy feast is observed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "when you observe a holy feast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. AT: "and you will be glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: as when one goes ... Rock of Israel
tn.text: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Yahweh having the power to protect his people is spoken of as if he were a rock on which the people could climb and escape from enemies. AT: "to Israel's protective rock" or "which is like a protective rock for Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: show the motion of his arm
tn.text: Here "arm" represents the power of God. It is implied that Yahweh will show his power by destroying his people's enemies. AT: "show that he is powerful by destroying your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: in storming anger and flames of fire
tn.text: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it were a storm or a fire. AT: "in anger that is like a storm and flames of fire" or "in great anger" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"with storms full of wind, rain, and hail"
hard pieces of ice that fall from the sky like rain

tn.ref: For at the voice of Yahweh, Assyria will be shattered
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "For when Yahweh speaks he will shatter the soldiers of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Isaiah speaks of Assyria's fear as if Assyria is an object that Yahweh's voice shatters. AT: "Assyria will be terrified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here this represents the soldiers of Assyria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Every stroke of the appointed rod that Yahweh will lay on them
tn.text: Yahweh causing an army to defeat the Assyrians is spoken of as if Yahweh would hit the Assyrians with a rod. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people of Judah will accompany it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This is a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:05:11|5:12]].

tn.ref: he battles and fights with them
tn.text: Yahweh causing the enemy army to defeat the Assyrians is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who would fight along with the enemy army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For a place of burning was prepared long ago
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "For long ago Yahweh prepared a place for burning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This phrase is the meaning of the word "Topheth." Topheth is a place in the Hinnom Valley, south of Jerusalem, where at one time people burned their children as sacrifices to a false god. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: it is prepared for the king
tn.text: It is implied that this refers to the king of Assyria. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh prepared it for the king of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The pile is ready with a fire and much wood
tn.text: "The pile is ready with much wood to make a fire"

tn.ref: The breath of Yahweh, like a stream of brimstone, will set it on fire
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh's breath as if it were a river of fire that will set the pile on fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
